avoidant-choreography.title: avoidant choreography
avoidant-choreography.text: tá daoine lán le filíocht people are so full of poetry. i only heighten it. tune a ghost's voice, and the book writes itself. in my dreaming i hear: a humpback whale mimicking extinct animals, trees shifting their bones, geological time splitting open, a fairy princess made of sparks. my phone charged to maximum on a four-hour bus from dublin, my social battery exhausted, i transubstantiate to my grandmother's back bedroom. photos re-found, aunties placing them in new frames before the priest arrives. busy in avoidant choreography. i made it back just before her eyes grew fixed, as if she'd spotted a bargain in a rummage-sale bin.

the-patron-saint-of-vhs.title: the patron saint of vhs
the-patron-saint-of-vhs.text:
yvonne had cartoon lips,
drawn by someone
who'd never seen a real mouth.

she worked in the video shop,
stocking what the town wouldn't rent.

she slipped us films like gifts,
passwords to better worlds:
lynch. jarmusch. waters.
weird was a country
we could emigrate to.

the video shop is now a phone shop.
and yvonne is a name i google sometimes,
finding nothing.
which feels about right.

some people
rewind you
and watch you go.

fossils-and-lichen.title: fossils and lichen
fossils-and-lichen.text:
there is a theory
that visions of saints
are just neuroelectric misfires.
epilepsy.
maybe tumors.

another that says
a hag pressing on your sleeping sternum
or banshees at the window
are only glitches.
the body paralyzed by sleep.
the mind ablaze.

there are those who believe
abductions are just
coded desires.
repression dressed in silver suits.
forceps in the last century.
laser cutters in the next.
the tools evolve.
the fantasy stays the same.

some believe
there's a city underground.
ancient machines
waiting to wake up.
because we're only renters here.

there are fossils
older than the first oceans.
rivers teeming with creatures
smarter than silicon ever could be.
there is lichen
more interesting
than the world's headlines
put together.

between one breath
and the next,
the world wiggles a little.
stay still, and you might hear it —
the almost-music.

solar-boat.title: solar boat
solar-boat.text:
you fell asleep on my chest,
small furnace of a body,
breath like tide,
in and out, regular as planets.

your hand opened and closed,
grasping at dreams,
at milk, at comfort,
at the unknowable things
babies reach for.

someday you'll be embarrassed
that i wrote this,
that i made you public property,
a symbol, a metaphor.

tonight you're just warm,
just heavy with sleep,
just a solar boat
sailing across my ribs,
carrying the sun inside you.

a-good-drying-day.title: a good drying day
a-good-drying-day.text:
british soldiers in saracens
is not a memory i own.
instead, it's the morning the young squaddie said hello,
crouched behind a dividing wall
on my way to school.
his thick birmingham accent,
seventeen, maybe eighteen,
the distorted muzzle, typographic
against the snow.
i wanted to put my finger there,
and feel its perforations.

on my last day of school
i met no one.
it was so hot i tied my blazer
around my bony hips.
a good drying day.

i fell into a room with no good corners,
dreams held in a trapped body.
i knew there was craft in a distant machine
but couldn't make contact.
the tolerances were too fine.
i was lost without our catholic conventions.
you, my anchor, were in pimlico.
i drifted on waterloo street.

if i'd known, i would have
made,
and made,
and made,
because what little i did construct
was hollow, second-hand.

so now when you say there is so much you want to do
but you have no time,
i stay with you
and we sit with it

wild-loops.title: wild loops
wild-loops.text:
the cherry picker
looked unsteady
from my point of view.
its talon could
quite likely
careen through the windscreen.

ensconced
beside the september-morning
mini-market:
toilet paper and a mammy
with her hair in curlers.
wild loops of pink plastic,
setting her intentions for the day.

the dog would not advance
any further; his path's
vanishing point snagged
by blackberry brambles.

bogside bad lads, contorted in the wild,
picking over feral hoops of tyre
where the rubber met the road.
career pallet-diggers,
sniffing out the good stuff.

their half-finished construction:
a mass of lines and planes,
a battlefield of perspective.
you say yes,
they say no.

rewilding.title: rewilding
rewilding.text:
we spread out along the riverbank,
strangers with sandwiches and good boots.

"she drove off the side of the glenshane pass.
no other car was involved" —
an incongruous opener
for a picnic by the river.

his sister had studied microbiology
before their accident.
i nodded,
relaxing into his story,
like descending
into a barrel of ice water.

he spoke of hannibal's elephants,
carthage over the himalayas.
(our tapenade and crackers,
had been vacuum-packed
in an industrial unit in pennyburn.)

later we climbed knockery,
paused at caterpillars,
moths in chrysalis.

his corpuscular retelling
gave him salve,
some solace.
his sister sounded remarkable.

then a woman spoke of her exhibition
in a presbyterian museum —
about the last camera factory in ireland.

another man talked of his skin cancer,
excised under local anaesthetic;
halfway through
the numbness faded,
and he described
the sawing motion,
like tearing
a plastic shopping bag.

we passed remnants
of the american naval tenancy,
nissan huts gone,
concrete paths
driven through rhododendrons —
enough once
to make a colonial lady
complain to the major.
those tanks, in time,
ended up
on normandy beaches.

on our way home in banbridge
i bought my son
an underage cider.
a family of six squealed
through a carvery
beneath crayons and ketchup.

he said he would rewild the barren escarpment
of the mournes,
smoky scots pine,
rain from far away,
     falling diagonally
          against the palimpsest
               of the isle of man
                    and sugarloaf.

calibri-bodies-we-are.title: calibri bodies (we are)
calibri-bodies-we-are.text:
welcome to the show —
we are calibri bodies.
we backflip for pennies
and leave our faces bloody.
we know not of any band
that contends to be our equal,
so take a step towards us
and grab yourself an earful.

counting in —
counting out —
count on us to raze the stage,
bending double,
in warp spasm,
pounding water,
needing no one.

we have driven for miles
to see your tired faces,
invoke your flagging spirits,
and leave our epic contrails.

we are a trifle hotter
than the devil's entry fee.
we are new reckless authors,
punk's thrilling killing spree.

we are everyone and nobody,
we are calibri bodies.
we are the world's catharsis —
watch us take all the money.

manhattan-petrichor.title: manhattan petrichor
manhattan-petrichor.text:
i could tell from his stride
that a crime was about to unfold
parked in an uber
at an unrequested gas stop
minutes from jfk
he slung his backpack in the door jamb
and emerged with multiple six-packs
filled the satchel
then strolled across the forecourt
an exasperated sales assistant
breached his perspex cocoon
and shouted into the dark
but his saunter didn't alter
not even a trot
my driver clicked the central locking shut
i slunk in the back
a retreating hedgehog

we took off into early evening
and the rain started
lifting oil from the tarmac
and then i was elsewhere
smells from the dashboard
rose into my one working nostril
sandalwood maybe
commingled with vietnamese pop
and my podcast

i thought of the closest i ever
felt to my father
the night he took me to see a faith healer
on the journey i explained
how sampling and synthesis worked
and he listened like it really mattered

we waited on folding chairs
between profusely smoking
faithful
there to see the travelling wonder
and hold st patrick's tooth
one man was terrifyingly bent double
others hacked at scarred lungs
and some were just there for the craic

my turn came quickly
and he asked me what the trouble was
a popped sinew in my right hand
he picked up the limb
and dipped his thumb
in some sort of chrism, an unguent
from a small, blue pot
rubbed the lump once, twice, three times
gone

i rolled my window down
and let the rain in

post-hope.title: post hope
post-hope.text:
boom.
this is the after.
the laughter is canned.
the future's been banned.
and the algorithm sells you band-aids
for your phantom limb.

post hope.

where the streetlights hum like dying gods,
"dream big" scrawled in sharpie
on a foreclosure sign,
where your phone buzzes
but it's just the grid
finding your pulse
and you think of the last time
your name meant
something to someone.

boom.

we measure days in hatescrolls,
count blessings in caffeine spoons,
praise the preachers of productivity
who baptize us in burnout
and canned holy water.

i saw hope last night.
she was bleeding pixels,
whispering:
"don't wait for me.
i'm just roadkill
on your timeline."

boom.

this is where the beats go hollow,
the blend between the tracks,
where the anthem is a dial tone,
and the chorus is rage
with a curfew.

but my mouth is still a weapon.
my breath, still percussion.
every word,
a flare gun
fired at the dark.

boom.

i am not done.
i am not.
i am.
i.
.

lipstick-snake.title: lipstick snake
lipstick-snake.text:
rolling stones t-shirt
lipstick snake
pentax camera
soft boy fake

girlfriend jacket
new band name
ironic antlers
oxbow lake

typewritten invite
doughnut wall
vitamin water
quarter inch tape

ogham tattoo
cheap cocaine
miraculous medal
closed debate

lukewarm coffee
conical flask
rescue puppy
double take

dogs in glasses
giant scarf
living salad
tax rebate

battered sausage
charcoal ice cream
goji berries
chips and peas

gaslighting manchild
talking shop
credit stealing
stomach knot

ukrainian mistress
carbon brakes
ass-kissing nemesis
ethereum stakes

lowercase logo
kombucha on tap
speak to me again
rubber band snap

archetypal-tarot.title: archetypal tarot
archetypal-tarot.text: at this kings cross restaurant the mint sauce is of questionable origin— grey, perfunctory. i have definitely eaten worse. an infinite chocolate fountain cascades before a badly keystoned bollywood film projected on the restaurant's screenless white wall. busboys in tight, crisply laundered shirts laugh conspiratorially, folding napkins, enjoying the slagging. a couple younger than us eat greedily by the window. these are not their first pints of cobra, happy in a childless pre-christmas bliss. a middle-aged woman reads conspicuously to my left. i suspect a religious text, given the book's form factor. her tiny clutch strap bisecting her belly, much as i have mine, we patiently await our orders. a birthday party tips out from downstairs. a wired, tip-hunting maître d' stalks them to the door. i can tell he's in charge by his green roll-neck and darting, calculating eyes. we were just like them in our twenties, eating overpriced sunday lunches in bucolic, pastiche-colonial bars near parliament fields. the projected singer in rose-tinted glasses gesticulates behind a chorus line, pointing like a 90s east coast rapper with bleached tips, his backup group pushing the air wildly to a reedy horn solo. the woman to my left flips her book excitedly to take a phone call, struggling to hit accept, the pad of her finger eclipsed by her acrylics. she sets down her book, fanning the spine: archetypal tarot.

one-to-stun-two-to-kill-three-to-make-su.title: one to stun, two to kill, three to make sure
one-to-stun-two-to-kill-three-to-make-su.text: you can tell your reflection you've done enough, decide to stop caring what people think. you can choose to accept that your belly hangs over your trousers. you can love wrinkles— proof you smiled once. you can learn to shoulder some self-respect. one crazy heatwave. wildfires. twelve dead already. you can sing like no one's listening. you can ask the girl if she's dancing. two washed up on the beach. shackled. translucent. you can grow old with disgrace, make a nuisance, enemies. you can learn to live with guilt. you can let your garage fill with silt. three. hulk hogan is dead. "whatcha gonna do when hulkamania runs wild over you?" eat your vitamins. say your prayers. today is your best season— there is nothing more one to stun, two to kill, three to make sure.

works-event.title: works event
works-event.text: i went to your works event, you left me by the dripping ice sculpture, talking to the german guy from legal about his lost cat and the number of points on his boots card. i set up the laptop for your presentation, and cut in funny videos against company updates, making transitions land on scripted beats. | i stayed for the whole of the works dinner and nodded obsequiously to a data analyst from zurich about her passive-aggressive downstairs neighbour who insists he can hear her walking about no matter what she puts on her feet. i went to the scavenger hunt, where i drew the card to be the mayor's mistress. when the judgement scene was enacted i squealed 'but i've always loved you' and everyone stared because i was the only one still in character.

daytime-astronomy.title: daytime astronomy
daytime-astronomy.text: we walked the river roe ash, elm, oak and yew, invasive and native. you relayed their etymology on a damp park bench beside a council-issue bin populus tremula whispering overhead. we noted gaps in the city where green tears up concrete, roots barge bitumen, snarled in melancholy optimism dealing with the situation. the cheapside london plane is struck often by vandals but implacable against 2 for 1s and cut price cosmetics, dapples sunlight across swathes of ice cream eaters.

cut-short.title: cut short
cut-short.text:
they washed the gravel
with some industrial powder.
in the end, they dug the blood out.

some ran from the veranda,
most stood stock still.
mr. fullerton was first on the scene.
cradled his head with a tracksuit top.

the crossbars were taken down,
blazers weren't ripped that day.
prefects absent from the corridors.
we still kept to the right.

he could name any car
from the sound of its exhaust.
he lived round the corner,
so we had a shared
primary school walk—
adidas bags rattling with empty lunch boxes.

we were given the day off,
came to the funeral in uniform.
third years stood at the back of the cathedral
by the mechanical votive candles.
when they set down the coffin
his mother screamed
over folk group guitars.

no-matter-how-dark-my-thinking-would-bec.title: no matter how dark my thinking would become
no-matter-how-dark-my-thinking-would-bec.text:
each time the dog escaped
an unlatched bolt,
a forgotten front door
i blamed myself,
an owner too loose
with the world.

it took me until now
to understand
he was wiser
than i could imagine.

twelve years
of walking pavements together,
his sniffs and stops
a map
i could never read
a magnetic field
of sense.

this fugitive hound
would never step
into traffic,
no matter
how dark
my thinking
would become.

word-spread-quickly.title: word spread quickly
word-spread-quickly.text: word spread quickly of a neighbours downed fence a great storm - bigger than we'd ever known had them running for the breakers in cúil chaorach it took great pleasure upending forgotten toys, beach furniture and garden tools - untouched since last spring excitement grew between spikes in the mobile network conifers unfurled their anxiety, quiescent silt stirred wind shrieked with a voice of death as new fathers rummaged for candles cursing their ill-preparedness
